home.description: I'm an Assistant Professor at the University of Rochester Department of Physics and Astronomy.  I also hold a Visiting Scientist appointment at the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics. I'm primarily interested in observations of the very youngest protostars, in particular how asymmetric infall from the larger environment can influence properties of potentially planet-forming disks.  Ultimately I seek to unite dust, kinematic, chemical, and polarization observations of embedded protostars at multiple wavelengths and size scales to form a more nuanced picture of star and planet formation. I specialize in high-resolution (sub-arcsecond) interferometric observations. I also work closely with my theorist co-investigators.

description.text: I am currently most interested in studying streamers, particularly via the NOEMA PRODIGE Large Program.

disclaimer: The views expressed on this website are mine alone and do not necessarily reflect the views of the University of Rochester.

research.title: Streamers Feed Disks on the Verge of Planet Formation
research.sub_title: How do streamers change young planet-forming disks?

papers.title: PRODIGE: A NOEMA Large Program
authors: The First Large Observing Campaign Designed to Search for Streamers
papers.abstract: Streamers are long and skinny structures made of gas and dust.  They infall from large core and envelope scales and feed protostellar disks in the youngest phases of star formation. My collaborators, in particular the PRODIGE team, and I have made great efforts in characterizing the streamers' mass infall rates, how often they occur, chemical composition, shocks at the disk impact zone, and structural changes within the disk at planet forming scales that arise from infalling streamers. Although previously overlooked, due to recent upgrades in radio interferometer technology, streamers are now commonly found both in low and high-mass star forming regions.

research.title: Substructures in Young Protostellar Disks
research.sub_title: How early can planet formation begin?

papers.title: Four annular structures in a protostellar disk less than 500,000 years old
papers.abstract: We detect the youngest protostellar disk with multiple concentric rings and gaps around a Class I protostar. Older Class II sources have been detected previously with disk rings and gaps in abundance, and these features are often attributed to planet formation already well underway. Our work with the Class I protostar IRS 63 shows that the same features are already present at an evolutionary stage when the protostar will still gain significant mass from the surrounding envelope. The dust rings will act as an early foothold for dust grain growth, which is a prerequisite of planet formation. All together, this work is compelling evidence that protostars and planets grow and evolve together from very early times.

research.title: Class 0 and I Protostellar Disk Sizes
research.sub_title: How large and how early can disks grow?

papers.title: The VLA Nascent Disk and Multiplicity Survey of Perseus Protostars (VANDAM). V. 18 Candidate Disks around Class 0 and I Protostars in the Perseus Molecular Cloud
papers.abstract: We surveyed all young Class 0 and I protostars with VLA continuum observations in the Perseus Molecular Cloud in an effort to characterize embedded protostellar disk sizes and multiplicity fractions. Our study is the first to attempt to characterize embedded disk sizes in a complete and unbiased sample of an entire molecular cloud. The VANDAM survey has a resolution of ~15 au at 8 mm, and we found that 14 Class 0 and 4 Class I protostars had disks greater than 12 au in radius, based on modeling in the uv-plane. This left 78% of the protostars in our survey without clear signs of disks found.  These small radii at long wavelengths likely represent a lower limit on disk size, and while it is clear that large (greater than 10 au) disks can indeed exist even in the youngest Class 0 phase, large young disks are uncommon even with these high resolution data.

research.title: Polarization in Embedded Disks
research.sub_title: Under what conditions do magnetic fields rule?

papers.title: The Magnetic Field in the Class 0 Protostellar Disk of L1527
papers.abstract: Using the CARMA telecope, we used 50 au resolution 1.3 mm dust continuum obserbservations to study the polarization of the disk towards L1527.  L1527 is a well-known and edge-on Class 0 protostellar disk, and the first Class 0 disk to be confirmed via detection of Keplerian rotation. This work is the first to detect resolved polarization emission arising directly from a Class 0 disk. If the polarization is caused by spinning dust grains aligned with magnetic fields, then it is consistent with a toroidal magnetic field wrapped around a rotating disk. This suggests that at 50 au scales, the angular momentum transport in Class 0 protostars is driven by magnetorotational instabilities rather than magnetocentrifugal winds.  Since this paper was published, many other mechanisms for producing polarized emission in embedded disks have been found (such as self-scattering). Meanwhile, the morphology of the polarized emission in this edge-on Class 0 disk remains an observational benchmark for any proposed polarization mechanism.

papers.abstract: Under development: coming 2024. I grew up in a rural small town with my blue-collar family, and I want to contribute to the educations of students in similar situations. I'm currently working with teachers to develop modules of worksheets, lesson plans, activities, and teachersâ€™ notes aimed at bringing astronomy into classrooms. The modules will be published online for broad use by any teacher. We use astronomy themes to convey core math and science concepts required by Texas state education standards for graduation.

papers.title: Stars and Planets Grow Up Together as Siblings
papers.abstract: My new work, just published in Nature, shows compelling evidence that planets start to form while infant stars are still growing. With ALMA we studied IRS 63, a beautiful protostellar disk with the youngest known multiple rings and gaps.
